awd_titl_txt: L-amino acid taste activation in mice.
awd_abstract_narration: Activation of basic tastes (sweet, sour, salt, bitter and umami) help identify specific foods and signal dietary content.  In spite of their importance to biological functions, little is known about how the taste system detects L-amino acids. It is generally assumed that L-amino acids use the same taste receptor and cellular signal pathway that signals the taste of L-monosodium glutamate, but pilot data suggest that this is too simple. The hypothesis is that multiple taste receptors and two transduction pathways detect and signal L-amino acid tastes.  This research will test this hypothesis by comparing taste-related responses to three L-amino acids (L-glutamate, L-serine, L-arginine): 1) of isolated taste sensory cells using calcium imaging methods, 2) of normal mice and mice missing the primary glutamate taste receptor using behavioral methods, and 3) of neurons in the brain stem activated by taste signals from the tongue using antibody markers.  Pilot data suggest that at least two (maybe 3) taste receptors detect L-amino acids and the very interesting possibility that cross-talk between two transduction pathways within taste sensory cells modulate L-amino acid tastes.  The data also suggest that signals for L-amino acids travel in separate but overlapping neuronal pathways within the brain stem.  The results of this research will enable the chemosensory sciences to more directly link the taste qualities of L-amino acids with the biological mechanisms underlying L-amino acid tastes.  In turn, this will help health care professionals improve the palatability of foods containing these amino acids, thereby improving dietary intake.  Besides the scientific benefits, this project has significant additional broader impacts and will support several undergraduates and two graduate students with opportunities to gain hands-on experience with these research methods and experience the joys of scientific inquiry.

Background and General Hypothesis. Sensing basic tastes (sweet, sour, salt, bitter and umami) helps one identify specific foods and signal dietary content. It has been assumed that the tastes of L-amino acids are signaled by T1R1+T1R3 receptors, the same receptors that detect L-monosodium glutamate (MSG), but surprisingly little evidence supports this position. MSG elicits the prototypical taste of umami, which is potentiated by inositol monophosphate (IMP). However, our preliminary data argued that additional receptors could be involved. We hypothesized that multiple taste receptors are important in detecting the tastes of L-amino acid stimuli. We tested our hypothesis with three Objectives using five L-amino acids and several techniques.

Research Activities and Results. For Objective 1, we studied isolated taste sensory cells with calcium imaging (measuring Ca2+ concentration within a cell) to assess their responses to L-amino acids. If the T1R1+T1R3 receptor is the only one that detects all L-amino acids, then taste sensory cells should show similar increases in intracellular Ca2+ when stimulated by each of the five L-amino acids. However, after sampling a large population of cells, we learned that a taste cell that detects amino acids, may respond to one or more L-amino acid but rarely responds to all five L-amino acids. Adding IMP potentiated their response about half the time. These data show that taste sensory cells respond differentially (not uniformly) to L-amino acids. Importantly, taste sensory cells of mice with the T1R3 receptor deleted (-/-), also responded similarly to the five L-amino acids. Additional work using glutamate antagonists with wild type and knockout mice suggest that mGluR1 and mGluR4 receptors contribute to L-amino acid tastes. 

  Objective 2 used behavioral tests with wild type, T1R3-/-, and T1R1-/- mice to compare taste qualities of L-amino acids. Our primary method involved conditioned taste aversion in which the mouse is exposed to a novel taste, then made ill. The mouse associates its upset stomach with the novel taste and thereafter avoids the taste solution. They also avoid test solutions which elicit a similar taste (stimulus generalization). The greater the similarity between these solutions, the more the mouse avoids the test solution. Our hypothesis was that if all L-amino acids are detected by one receptor, then mice should perceive the tastes of all L-amino acids as the same. Wild type mice were evaluated with MSG, L-serine and L-arginine. The olfactory systems of all mice were made dysfunctional to control for odor cues. These mice showed strong generalization between MSG and L-serine but only weak generalization between L-arginine and either MSG or L-serine, suggesting that L-serine and MSG elicit similar tastes but L-arginine elicits a different taste sensation. The tastes of L-alanine and MSG were similarly compared with wild type mice. They showed strong bidirectional generalization of aversion. T1R3-/- mice could identify L-alanine and MSG, and they showed strong bidirectional generalization of aversion even though they were missing a key receptor.
